summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the Ghislaine Maxwell trial. The government seeks clarification on permissible cross-examination of pseudonymous witnesses and requests an order barring courtroom sketch artists from drawing exact likenesses of those witnesses.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case referenced (United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, 20 Cr. 330 (MN)).

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the Ghislaine Maxwell case, to whom this letter is addressed.

persons.name: Damian Williams

events.title: Pretrial Conference
events.description: A pretrial conference was held where the court discussed rules for cross-examining witnesses testifying under pseudonyms.

keyFacts: The government is seeking clarification from the court on the boundaries of cross-examination for witnesses testifying under pseudonyms, specifically regarding questions about the 'genre' of their careers.

The government argues that allowing detailed questioning about the specific type of movie or TV show a witness worked on (e.g., action movie vs. soap opera) creates a significant risk of identifying the witness and has no impeachment value.

The government also seeks a court order to bar courtroom sketch artists from drawing the exact likenesses of witnesses testifying under pseudonyms or first names, citing a similar order from the Raniere case.
The document references 'Minor Victims and witnesses' whose privacy the government is seeking to protect through these procedural requests.
